ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There was one live lecture each week, and most classes had a guest speaker.
Everything was virtual.
There were some seminar components
We had live virtual seminars every week. These sessions were also recorded to accommodate students who had to miss the live component for any reason.
Only virtual seminar.
na

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I was exposed to the different areas of Biomedical engineering, and had guest speakers almost every class to talk about their experiences. It was very interesting and opened my eyes up to new aspects of the field that I had not thought about.
I learned about several different application of biomedical engineering. The course gave me a much clearer understanding of what a career in biomedical engineering could be like.

I learned a lot about the field of Biomedical Engineering and the different fields in it. It is a great course to take if you want to learn about what Biomedical Engineering is and whether you want to major in the field.
I learned a general overview of the field of Biomedical Engineering, from research to industry work, and even the different tracks that the major has to offer.

I got a good sense as to the different branches of biomedical engineering and what the opportunities are in each. I was inspired hearing from other students and their personal journeys in the major. This gave me some clarity about what I want to do with my degree.
This course gave me a thorough understanding of the potential paths and undertakings of someone who becomes a receives a biomedical engineering degree.
Overview of the various subfields of biomedical engineering.
We discussed the different fields within biomedical engineering through guest lectures.
How to form connections, about the BME major
I learned more about BME and the different career pathways.

By taking BENG 280, I learned a lot about the various tracks and career paths that exist within the field of biomedical engineering. I was able to learn about the research done by various faculty members at Yale, and this was helpful in understanding how biomedical innovation translates from the lab to the clinic. Also, hearing from people in industry was also great, as it provided another perspective on what biomedical engineers do outside of academia. Finally, this class offered a great opportunity to reflect on my own goals and consider why I really want to pursue biomedical engineering as a major.
I developed a rudimentary understanding of the real-world applications and pathways of biomedical engineering post-Yale.

I was introduced to the research that happens in BME. Also importantly, this was the first time I was introduced to research in industry and how companies play a role in science (via the group project).
I learned more about the different fields and topics that biomedical engineering encompasses and some of the career paths it has to offer.
Learn about the fields covered by biomedical engineering. Helpful for thinking about what you want to do with the major
i learned so much about the field of biomedical engineering, the many different paths you can take with it, and all it has to offer!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would have liked to have more guest speakers on biomechanics/medical device design, as that is a main interest of mine, as well as fellow students.
The course was pretty chill and we go to hear from several areas in BME, which was nice in an otherwise heavy schedule. I would have liked to get out grades back a bit faster, but that's about it.

The speakers were all very informative and helpful. The array of topics chosen was diverse and addressed multiple interests in the class. The virtual format was a slight weakness, and I'm sure it would have been even more engaging in person.
There was a lot of great guest speakers and upperclassmen involvement which was great.
The strength of this course is Professor Miller-Jensen herself. She was open to providing her incite and guidance to all who asked!

This course brought in a lot of expertise throughout the BME world and I found it to be very insightful.

The projects we did in class were appropriately challenging as well, given the nature of the course. 

Including student panels about research and internships was also a great segment.

As an addition to the course, I would include a panel on first jobs out of undergrad and a panel about graduate school opportunities. There is a lot I am curious about that I didnt get to learn in this seminar.

This class does a great job of incorporating various types of insights such as bme professors, students currently pursuing a degree in bme, students who have started bme ventures, bme proffesionals in industry, and more.
There wasnt always a universal structure to the guest lecture, but many were very engaging and informative.
The assignments could use more direction. I struggled with the group project as others were not engaged as I was, so it was a struggle.
The strengths of the course was that it was not a stressful class and it was an introductory of showing the diversity of BME.

One strength of this course is that the assignments were not very challenging, yet offered good opportunities to self-reflect on what interests us about biomedical engineering. Also, I really enjoyed having the different speakers come and talk to us about their work, as in my other classes it is often hard to connect course concepts with real world translation of biomedical technology. I do not have any weaknesses to list, as the flexibility of this course actually benefited me a lot. This is because I was able to take the time to consider why I am choosing BME and also consider some potential career paths that I can pursue using this major.

The only thing I would have liked to seen is more information about the non-traditional career paths that Yale BME grads follow (for example, consulting, finance, law/medicine, etc.). It was nice to hear about research and industry, however as a pre-med student also considering other career paths such as consulting, I would have liked to hear more from past students who chose a job that the typical BME major does not take up.

There is a low course load and the speakers were engaging. One thought would be to move this earlier in students' careers, starting in freshman spring perhaps, so students have more time to decide what they wish to purse in undergrad.

I really liked the guest speakers. One that stuck out included Prof. Campbell who's presentation was amazing because he took his project all the way from one patient to a commercialized lab technique. Another was 3Derm which was inspiring because of how well spoken Liz was and of course since it's a Yale startup story. A weakness was that I don't think we as students engaged with the speakers as much as we would have if we were in person. It's also a bit of a setting the tone kind of thing where after the first couple classes it became a set routine that only one student would ask questions and everyone else would stay silent. Really getting people to engage on the first couple days could be a way to set the standard for the rest of the term.

The course is strong in that it allows students to gauge their interest in biomedical engineering and discover whether this major is the right one for them. Another point that is both a strength and weakness of the course is that the level of engagement is pretty low, so depending on what you prefer, this may be an issue.
The Q&A panels were very great  I enjoyed them the most. The pre-class questions were helpful in making sure that we had a little introduction to what was going to be talked about that day
I enjoyed the format of this course. There would be guest speakers almost every seminar, which gave really fun and helpful lectures in terms of their field. I learned alot!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall, online did not affect this class too much. I wish I would have had the opportunity to meet Prof KMJ, as well as the guest lecturer in person, and build connections.
The use of breakout rooms was helpful with different panelists and speakers. It would have been nice to have even more breakout rooms to get to know fellow BME students better.
We had projects where we would have to collaborate with other students in the class and talk to the professor.
The virtual presentations and panels succeeded beautifully. The professor and TA used the break-out room feature successfully to facilitate small group discussions as well.
The course was well adapted for online instruction.
Being able to actually see demonstrations.
I liked how there were weekly 1-2 questions about a journal or article to prepare us for the weeks presentation.

I think that the live interaction component of this course was great, as I got to discuss my ideas with other students and ask questions to the speakers that had conversations with us about their line of work. I also appreciated that the seminars were recorded, as I could go back and listen to parts of research talks over again to improve my understanding.

The live-seminar format worked optimally and the small groups were engaging. Nothing really stood out as a weakness, but the conversations in breakout rooms could stagnate if students weren't directly interested in what the upperclassman was studying.
Most things including the lectures and panels worked well. One thing that was hard because of the pandemic was the group project  coordinating with everyone was difficult.
The virtual seminar was great as it allowed us to get the next best thing when trying to meet and learn from different professionals and professors in biomedical engineering.
very good format for this course.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely, even if you are not sure you want to major in BME, this class is a great opportunity to learn about the field, hear from current BME students, and learn about the research of current faculty.
Yes, it a relatively low stress course in which you will also get to hear from people doing very cool things in science. It's also a great way to meet others in the BME major.

Definitely! Whether you're a BME major and have to take it or if you're simply interested in the field, it's a great overview of biomedical engineering and very helpful in deciding what areas of BME are most interesting to you. Also, it's a fairly low-stress environment with only a few major assignments throughout the semester, so if you're taking a heavy load, don't sweat also taking BENG 280.
This course is excellent for any student considering studying BME. If you are debating between majors or aren't sure which concentration to focus on, I'd highly recommend it.
If you are deciding on majoring in Biomedical Engineering, take this class because it teaches about the different branches of the field and what Yale offers.
Yes! If you are interested in Biomedical Engineering and want a general overview of things without much of a workload, then this is definitely a safe space to explore.
Anyone interested in having a relaxed, yet engaging introduction to biomedical engineering should take this.
This course is required for bme majors however I would strongly recommend this course for anyone interested in learning more about bme.
Yes! A relaxing class that taught more of the street-smarts than book-smart content! SO useful!
Yes and its also a requirement but it helps.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone considering biomedical engineering as a potential major or career path. I know it is a requirement for the major, but this course taught me a lot about the different divisions within biomedical engineering as well as the employment possibilities post-graduation. In addition, this course gives you an opportunity to reflect on if biomedical engineering is right for you and hear from various speakers in industry and research. It also helps that this is a pretty light class in terms of workload, but regardless I would highly recommend.
I would recommend this course because it gives a concise introduction into BME.
Yes  it's a great way to learn more about what BME is and what the opportunities to get involved at Yale are. Plus, Prof. Miller Jensen is so kind and engaged it always brightened my day to see her.

I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in or considering majoring in biomedical engineering. Even if you are not, and you just want to learn about the field, this is a great course for that too.

This is a great course if you are considering the major. Really introduces you to various aspects and helps you think about what you want to do. This is also the only half credit course I've taken that truly has a half-credit workload.

If you are looking to decide if you want to continue with Biomedical engineering for a major, i would take this course! It shows you not only professionals in this field, but also are exposed to older students who tell you more about the major as you move through college, and as well as tips for internships/labs/ etc. which are super useful! also helps you network with older students and professors/professionals!
